item.content:encoded:
Hadi Khalilia from DataScientia attended the 2024 Joint International Conference on Computational Linguistics, Language Resources, and Evaluation (LREC-COLING 2024), which took place in Torino for three days.

The conference brought together linguistic experts who study language from diverse perspectives. Discussions covered various topics, including computational linguistics, speech, multimodality, and natural language processing. The conference’s main focus was evaluating and developing resources to support work in these areas.

The event was supported by the ELRA Language Resources Association (ELRA) and the International Committee on Computational Linguistics (ICCL), two major international players in computational linguistics.

Hadi Khalilia presented the LiveLanguage initiative to enhance ArabicWordNet (AWN) by closing lexical gaps and expanding synsets. A key reference was the paper “Advancing the Arabic WordNet: Elevating Content Quality,” in which DataScientia researchers introduced the updated AWN V3 version. The LiveLanguage methodology expanded and corrected lemmas, added new glosses, and provided example sentences.

Here below the paper’s abstract:

High-quality WordNets are crucial for achieving high-quality results in NLP (Natural Language Processing) applications that rely on such resources. However, the wordnets of most languages suffer from serious issues of correctness and completeness with respect to the words and word meanings they define, such as incorrect lemmas, missing glosses and example sentences, or an inadequate, Western-centric representation of the morphology and the semantics of the language. Previous efforts have largely focused on increasing lexical coverage while ignoring other qualitative aspects.

In this paper, we focus on the Arabic language and introduce a major revision of the Arabic WordNet that addresses multiple dimensions of lexico-semantic resource quality. As a result, we updated more than 58% of the synsets of the existing Arabic WordNet by adding missing information and correcting errors. In order to address issues of language diversity and untranslatability, we also extended the wordnet structure by new elements: phrasets and lexical gaps.

The full paper is available here.

Keywords: WordNet, NLP, language, Arabic language, diversity, wordnet, phraset, lexical semantics.

item.content:encoded:
On September 7, 2023, The Guardian published an article about the risks and limitations of AI translation tools used by U.S. migration agencies.

The newspaper features insights from Gárbor Bella, a member of our Data Scientia community. According to scholars, these tools fall short of capturing linguistic diversity and interpreting cultural nuances, which are crucial for accurate translation.

Despite these obstacles, Gárbor Bella remains optimistic about AI language translators. He believes language diversity can help overcome these challenges and promote equal opportunities. The researcher believes it can be implemented through data catalogs based on cross-lingual lexical semantics. Catalogs can be created by engaging professionals and native speakers worldwide.

Read more in the Guardian in the article “Lost in AI translation: growing reliance on language apps jeopardizes some asylum applications.”

Keywords: language, translation, AI-powered translators, artificial intelligence, linguistic diversity, catalog, culture, migration, cross-lingual lexical semantics, intervie

item.dc:creator: Tetiana Bihun

item.content:encoded:
The Data Scientia Event 2024 has successfully concluded and took place at the University of Trento in the Department of Sociology in Italy. The Department, located in the city’s historic heart and surrounded by mountains, served as the venue for the gathering. We are eager to share our key takeaways from the event.

The DataScientia Event: Community, Projects, and Education 2024 successfully united international participants from diverse backgrounds to collaborate on AI development. The Data Scientia event brought together 65 participants from diverse academic backgrounds, representing regions including Central Asia, Africa, South Asia, Europe, East Asia, the Middle East, and South America. Participants included professors, PhD candidates, researchers, and industry professionals from countries such as Kazakhstan, South Africa, India, Spain, Cyprus, Turkey, France, Uzbekistan, Mozambique, China, Uganda, Taiwan, Mongolia, Qatar, Palestine, Iran, Paraguay, and Italy.

The event invited the Data Scientia Community to discuss past, ongoing, and future projects and initiatives. It also welcomed anyone interested in learning about Data Scientia’s collaborative projects and educational initiatives. Therefore, the main focus was reinforcing and expanding Data Scientia’s partnerships. 

The three-day Data Scientia event consisted of a dynamic series of presentations, workshops, and discussions. The event agenda included innovative projects in education, data collection, language, and data management.  It featured engaging discussions, beneficial workshops, and valuable exchanges of experience, strengthening existing collaborations while encouraging new visitors to join the community. 

We would like to thank everyone who contributed to this event. Our appreciation goes to the speakers who presented their projects and led workshops and the participants who traveled worldwide to attend the Data Scientia event. Together, we are shaping the future of AI, data science, language, knowledge representation, and education.

We believe that the Data Scientia community will grow and, through our united efforts, create a better future for everyone. The Data Scientia always welcomes innovative ideas, and we are open to new collaborations to grow.

Follow our news to join our next DataScientia event and other projects!

Keywords: collaboration, partnership, diversity, education, data collection, and language data management.

item.title: LiveLanguage Kinship Study Featured in Frontiers
item.dc:creator: Tetiana Bihun
item.description: On November 20, 2023, the journal Frontiers in Psychology published an article titled “Lexical Diversity in Kinship Across Languages and Dialects” by members of DataScientia who specialize in creating high-quality, diversity-aware lexical databases for natural language processing and machine translation. …
item.content:encoded:
On November 20, 2023, the journal Frontiers in Psychology published an article titled “Lexical Diversity in Kinship Across Languages and Dialects” by members of DataScientia who specialize in creating high-quality, diversity-aware lexical databases for natural language processing and machine translation. The article’s authors are Hadi Khalilia, Gábor Bella, Fausto Giunchiglia, Abed Alhakim Freihat, and Shandy Darma.

The paper was published as part of the research on The Adaptive Value of Languages: Non-Linguistic Causes of Language Diversity. The goal was to explore how natural environments or human-made influences might shape some features of language structure. Due to the tasks’ complexity, researchers from various fields, including linguistics, psychology, biology, sociology, and anthropology, were invited to contribute.

The paper was dedicated to finding specific concepts and gaps across various languages and dialects. The scholars proposed a unique method to capture linguistic diversity based on systematic data collection of specific narrowed areas rather than the general topic.

This method is designed to represent concepts specific to different languages and dialects while also addressing gaps in vocabulary. It has already been tested in two studies on kinship terms in Arabic dialects and the Indonesian language.

Here below the paper’s abstract:

Languages are known to describe the world in diverse ways. Across lexicons, diversity is pervasive, appearing through phenomena such as lexical gaps and untranslatability. However, in computational resources, such as multilingual lexical databases, diversity is hardly ever represented. In this paper, we introduce a method to enrich computational lexicons with content relating to linguistic diversity. 

The method is verified through two large-scale case studies on kinship terminology, a domain known to be diverse across languages and cultures: one case study deals with seven Arabic dialects, while the other one with three Indonesian languages. Our results, made available as browseable and downloadable computational resources, extend prior linguistics research on kinship terminology, and provide insight into the extent of diversity even within linguistically and culturally close communities.

Read the full paper on Frontiers in Psychology.

Keywords: linguistic diversity, lexical gaps, untranslatability, computational lexicons, multilingual lexical databases, kinship terminology, Arabic dialects,  semantic diversity, cross-cultural analysis, terminology databases.

item.title: What role will AI play in shaping our future?
item.dc:creator: Tetiana Bihun
item.description: The recent breakthrough in artificial intelligence (AI) stands as one of the most significant technological advancements of our time. With the rapid development of AI tools such as chatbots, AI editors, image generators, and various plugins, many people have already …
item.content:encoded:
The recent breakthrough in artificial intelligence (AI) stands as one of the most significant technological advancements of our time. With the rapid development of AI tools such as chatbots, AI editors, image generators, and various plugins, many people have already had the opportunity to test and explore these exciting innovations. AI’s transformative impact shines brightly in the digital and virtual reality realms.

Fausto Giunchiglia, the founder of Data Scientia, shares his vision for AI and the empowering strategies scientists can adopt to harness this technology for the greater good of humanity. He focuses on AI’s impact in the real world rather than its applications on the web. 

For him, AI is not only about the virtual world; AI should be integrated into all aspects of our lives. AI should improve people’s lives and bring joy to our lives. To illustrate, AI can enhance our enjoyment of cooking by finding recipes or helping us select the best restaurants. In sports, AI can assist with exercise routines like jogging. It can also enrich our cultural experiences by offering deeper insights into ancient civilizations and enhancing our understanding of the past through virtual tourism.

The scholar points out that while 20 years ago these experiences were primarily physical, many have now transitioned to digital formats. Today, we have digital heritage and virtual experiences that were previously unimaginable, providing new ways to connect with the world.

But what comes next? Given the increasing digitalization of our everyday activities, how can we further enjoy our lives and the real world?

Fausto envisions AI as a tool to build better lives by fostering connections with friends and family and enhancing our overall quality of life. AI has the potential to assist in numerous ways, from planning events to enriching cultural experiences. For instance, AI can tailor the experience to your interests and provide personalized insights if you’re exploring a museum or learning about a new culture. AI also has applications in the culinary world, helping us understand and appreciate different foods and enhancing our present experiences. Looking to the future, AI’s role will only grow as current achievements will soon become part of our past.

Central to Fausto’s vision is the concept of person-centered data. This type of data, which people share about their lives, is highly personal and not typically posted on social media. It includes intimate information about oneself and one’s family that is kept private. By utilizing this personal data, AI can significantly improve our lives and the lives of our loved onesIn conclusion, AI should focus on what is important for the future of humanity. Data Scientia strives to bring this vision to life by harnessing the power of AI to enhance the quality of life for all people.

Keywords: AI, technology, virtual tourism, digital heritage, foundational models, machine learning,  digitalization, private data, AI tools, AI applications, human-centric AI, data privacy.

item.content:encoded:
On September 7, 2023, The Guardian published an article about the risks and limitations of AI translation tools used by U.S. migration agencies.

Illustration: Nicole Rifkin/The Guardian

The newspaper features insights from Garbor Bella, a member of our Data Scientia community. According to the scholar, these tools fall short of capturing linguistic diversity and interpreting cultural nuances crucial for accurate translation.

   Language is more than a series of words and their meanings; it’s a means to express cultural identity, and it’s how many communities make sense of the world.

Bella Garbor

Despite these obstacles, Garbor Bella remains optimistic about AI language translators. He believes language diversity can help overcome these challenges and promote equal opportunities. The researcher believes it can be implemented through data catalogs based on cross-lingual lexical semantics. Catalogs can be created by engaging professionals and native speakers worldwide.

Keywords: language, translation, AI-powered translators, artificial intelligence, linguistic diversity, catalog, culture, migration, cross-lingual lexical semantics, interview
